content.webTitle: The Crayonettes: Playing Out | The ones we missed | CD review

fields.headline: The Crayonettes: Playing Out - review
fields.bodyText: A group of robots rust in the rain. A sweet lies on the floor, tempting even though it is covered with hair. A child walks home in the dark, frightened that every shadow is a monster. It's fair to say that Playing Out is more downbeat than the average children's album; add in the musical sophistication of tracks like Illegal, a sultry blend of doo-wop and funk, and you might suspect it's not made for children at all. But that would be unfair to the Crayonettes – folk singer Kathryn Williams and her punky pal Anna Spencer – and their ability to reflect the surreal meanderings of a child's imagination in the way that, say, Lewis Carroll did. Their songs are witty, silly and gently instructive, sufficiently simple for a child to love, but with enough depth that they don't drive parents mad. In other words, as children's music goes, Playing Out is the holy grail.
